title: documentation ongoing
body:
tracks changes made to documentation, which is ongoing rather that happening in chunks like other issues

- Xcode: [Re: warning: no debug symbols in executable (-arch i386)](http://lists.apple.com/archives/Xcode-users/2008/Oct/msg00569.html)

- Git
    - Branching Model
        - *needed for Accessor, to distinguish active from development copy of app
git-workflow-#103*
    - [revert a faulty merge](https://github.com/git/git/blob/master/Documentation/howto/revert-a-faulty-merge.txt)
    - [How to fix committing to the wrong Git branch?](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2941517/how-to-fix-committing-to-the-wrong-git-branch)
    - [Undo a pushed merge with git](http://www.christianengvall.se/undo-pushed-merge-git/)
    - [Revert multiple git commits](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1463340/revert-multiple-git-commits)
    - [How to undo (almost) anything with Git](https://github.com/blog/2019-how-to-undo-almost-anything-with-git)

git squash
    - *emacs commands: ^xC exit; ^xS save; ^K kill; ^W cutLine; ^Y paste*
    -` git rebase -i HEAD~#<number of revisions to squash>`
    - edit commands (pick, squash, ...); save; (exit?)
    - edit comment

- workflow supports new tools, including:
   - AppCode: IDE that is superior to Xcode for working with Xcode projects
    - waffle.io: Kanban board to "work better with GitHub issues"
    - TeamCity: continuous integration
- Git Workflow
    - add versioning, with release and hot fix branches
    - update merges and pushes involving master branch
- all Support targets run and test successfully under AppCode, Xcode, TeamCity
- functionality of script validateHTML available from AppCode

title: refactor shell scripts

milestone.title: stableDev
milestone.description:
stable, standardized development environment
    includes consistency among all projects in all repositories
support and implement new CCDev scripts, project style

body:
- probably convert each to bash (#99) first
- use conventions: - see [Bash conventions](https://bashinglinux.wordpress.com/2009/08/01/conventions/)
- refactor: _install scripts take $CCDev as a parameter (let TeamCity avoid overwriting local CCDev by injecting dependency from calling environment)
    - execInstallScript
        - what it does: set up parameters; support getting debugging info; dispatch callbacks
        - set up parameters interferes with having caller handle that responsibility;  debugging info would be better handled by logger; dispatch of callbacks could (should?) be handled by ccInstall

- [ ] use `sourceRoot="$(pwd)"; targetFolder="<targetName>"`
- [ ] ccInstall calls callback functions directly, eliminating need for execInstallScript and allowing parameters to be established directly by \*_install scripts
        - *msg=$(getSubtargetDestination "$subtarget"); es=$?*

title: environment variables

milestone.title: CI
milestone.description:
also requires [Accessor milestone CI](https://github.com/carolclark/Accessor/milestones/5/)
fully implement Continuous Integration using JetBrains TeamCity

body:
Our current build environments now include AppCode and TeamCity in addition to Xcode.
We had environment variables defined in Xcode, but that does not appear to have been reliable - the variables were redefined in many scripts. Now: - AppCode: We have not figured out how to define environment variables and have them available to scripts; defining with configuration seems to disappear frequently, and the variables are not available anyway (logging $CCDev value yields empty string). - TeamCity: We would like to have CCDev contents available as build artifacts. The default location for build artifacts is inside the checkout directory, e.g. Support. We do not know how to change that default location (may require updating to external database), and that location would be inappropriate for the other environments.

 

Variables affected: - $DEV - location of all projects and sources - use relative locations instead when possible - ccInstall also has function DEV to calculate that value - $CCDev - destination for most build output - probably should be injected to build scripts as a parameter

 

Parameters: - existing: - <"${SRCROOT}"> - available as $(pwd)? - < ${TARGET_NAME}> - should be supplied by script - < $(ACTION)> - new: - < $CCDev> - < $(ACTION)> ##### **Refactor Developer_install.ksh to Developer_build.sh** ##### improvements expected: change to bash; rename `install` to `copy_file` (Developer only); incorporate execInstallScript; change parameters, injecting $CCDev; $action: clean (project) | build | test | install
continue support for callbacks

title: switch to bash

milestone.title: stableDev
milestone.description:
stable, standardized development environment
    includes consistency among all projects in all repositories
support and implement new CCDev scripts, project style

body:
We have been using ksh for shell scripting. We have also considered switching to Python to handle that work due to issues in testing and debugging ksh.

Now:
- AppCode has a Bash plug-in
- Bash Automated Testing System (bats) is available and is TeamCity-compatible
- When looking at bash resources, useful information such as conventions and debugging, including a step Debugger, appear (not so for ksh)
- The work done by our shell scripts really is mostly shell commands. At least for now, since we do not have much experience with Python, shell scripting seems preferable.

Existing Files
- convert existing scripts to bash as needed to use available Bash support  features
    - *NB: rename(s) are a separate commit*
    - ccInstall

Third Party target group
    - *supports non-cocoa tools that cannot be installed via CocoaPods*
    - *includes document to support keeping track of revisions*
- [ ] move existing folder Support/Developer/Developer/Third Party, with its included folder ASUnit, to Support/Developer/Third Party
- [ ] add ReadMe.html, current_versions.html

Bash Support
- [ ] add additional bash support downloads to Third Party:
    - [Bash Automated Testing System](https://github.com/sstephenson/bats) (bats)
    - [bash-doxygen](https://github.com/Anvil/bash-doxygen)
    - [BASH debugger](http://bashdb.sourceforge.net)
- [ ] implement and install:
    - [ ] bats
    - [ ] bash-doxygen
    - [ ] bashdb

References:
- [BashSupport for IDEA](https://www.ansorg-it.com/en/products_bashsupport.html) - plugin
- [How to debug a bash script?](http://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/155551/how-to-debug-a-bash-script)
- [Debugging Bash scripts](http://tldp.org/LDP/Bash-Beginners-Guide/html/sect_02_03.html)
- [Advanced Bash-Scripting Guide: Debugging](http://tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/debugging.html)
- [Debugging with the BASH debugger](http://bashdb.sourceforge.net/bashdb.html)
- [Bash Hackers Wiki:Debugging a script](http://wiki.bash-hackers.org/scripting/debuggingtips)
- [Bash conventions](https://bashinglinux.wordpress.com/2009/08/01/conventions/)
- [UNIX tips: Learn 10 good UNIX usage habits](http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/aix/library/au-badunixhabits.html#five)
- [bash-doxygen](https://github.com/Anvil/bash-doxygen)
- [Bash Automated Testing System](https://github.com/sstephenson/bats) (bats) - less xUnit, but gives output in a format that can be handled directly by TeamCity
- [Xcode: Code Coverage](https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/DeveloperTools/Conceptual/testing_with_xcode/chapters/07-code_coverage.html)
- [We've Got You Covered](https://www.bignerdranch.com/blog/weve-got-you-covered/)
- [Bash Read a File Line By Line](http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/unix-howto-read-line-by-line-from-file/)
- [Bash Bits: Add colour output to your script](https://raymii.org/s/snippets/Bash_Bits_Add_Color_Output_To_Your_Scripts.html)
- [shell colors for tput](https://github.com/c00kiemon5ter/dotfiles/blob/master/.shell.colors.tput)
- [CocoaPods: Private Pods](http://guides.cocoapods.org/making/private-cocoapods.html)

title: safe Java installation
body:
When we started to install Java 8 build 71, it asked for permission to install a 'helper'. From our research, it appears that the 'helper' is an installer that also 'offers' (default: yes) to install other products, such as an Ask toolbar that may make Ask the default search engine.

Establish and document Java installation that installs Java only.

see [Java now installing adware](http://www.thesafemac.com/java-now-installing-adware/), maybe [Anti-Malware for Mac](https://www.malwarebytes.org/antimalware/mac/)

title: AppleScript schemes
body:
Current Xcode strategy is to have Xcode compile AppleScripts and put them into a bundle by associated target for later retrieval. 
Change to use osacompile to compile the source scripts and put them where they belong.

title: integrate targets

milestone.title: CI
milestone.description:
also requires [Accessor milestone CI](https://github.com/carolclark/Accessor/milestones/5/)
fully implement Continuous Integration using JetBrains TeamCity

body:
- targets, including failure generation and environment variables, operate consistently in all environments (AppCode, TeamCity, Xcode) - failing installer calls generate failures - all home-based folders are defined in environment variables - TeamCity writes to its own CCDev location

 

- environment variables $DEV, $CCDev: - Xcode, standalone Terminal: defined in ~/.kshrc, set up by DevConfig - ~~AppCode: defined in configurations; preset by default configurations~~ - apparently, path environment variables are not fully supported in AppCode - *we have not gotten them to work; functionality for defining path variables is documented for IntelliJ only* - DEV - *most uses are in tests; tests should probably not be looking for an absolute path anyway* - in files if needed, use relative definition: `DEV=${dir%/*}...` - CCDev: define CCDev=${HOME}/Library/CCDev in files for now - *drawbacks: TeamCity overwrites build data; defeats default way to access TeamCity artifacts* - *permanent solution (see 'switch to bash' #99) is to pass $CCDev as a parameter when *_install.ksh is called; expected to be part of a major refactoring* - TeamCity: defined in Root Project : Parameters - *to be addressed in 'environment variables' #100; continue defining within scripts for now*

 

- [x] execInstallScript.ksh: generate failures when indicated: replace 'return's with 'exit's - [x] edit AppCode's default configurations - [x] verify / establish environment variables for Xcode, TeamCity - [x] clean up environment variables - [ ] for each target (omit AppleScript schemes for now) - Steps: - set envvars $DEV, $CCDev for now; parent envvars on - *parameters to be dropped from standard *_install call soon; see 'switch to bash' #99* - generate failures when indicated: replace 'return's with 'exit's outside of callbacks - $HOME is not defined; 'carolclark' does not appear - define CCDev=${HOME}/Library/CCDev - for Cdoc build: incorrect folder causes findSources to fail, but build does not fail - findSources error fails - fix Support/Cdoc - for Docs builds, add candcsoft_host/public_html to output path - *addresses step in 'update Sites folder' #81 - DEV (search): in files where needed, use relative definition - Xcode: test - AppCode: test - TeamCity build steps: implement; verify all are executing as expected - [x] Developer - [x] refactor: move DevConfig file installation, testing to DevInstall - *improves control over exit codes and displayed messages* - [x] fetch latest changes to Git.html - *from HEAD~26, one of the commits to be reapplied* - *needed to verify processes for this issue and 'recover changes' #92* - [x] DoxyDemo - [x] Doxygen - *refactoring of action arguments was attempted here in refactor-action-#96; terminated for now because it will be easier and more productive to do that after bash tools have been adopted* - [x] Cdoc - [ ] Accessor documentation targets carolclark/Accessor#62 - [ ] 'fix findSources errors not failing' #111 - [ ] Python - [ ] Xcode - [ ] BBEdit

 

see also 'AppleScript schemes #97' for later

body:
Set up existing targets and tests for full testing and integration.

- [x] failing tests fail
    - *Some tests have been failing silently, logging errors to the build log but not returning non-zero exit code. There are visually apparent in AppCode, but are sometimes unavailable in Xcode, and will be misinterpreted by Continuous Integration.*
    - [x] reproduce non-failure error: use nonexistent path as installation argument; ccInstall findSources fails
    - [x] fix the missing error handling at that spot
    - [x] execInstallScript: uses exit <errorCode> instead of return
        - *execInstallScript is dotted in, so it is part of the original called script*
    - [x] verify that failure is recognized for Xcode; AppCode; CI
    - [x] fix the incorrect path
    - [x] Developer_install.ksh: while running DevConfig.ksh failing tests fail
- [x] ccInstall: report number of test files run
- [x] add AppCode plugin AppleScript IDEA
- [ ] install DoxyDemo issues
    - *does not identify target as Doxygen, so it calls getSubtargetDestination, which fails, but does not trigger failure*
    - *somewhere in this process, findSources has been called with incorrect directory; that has also failed, but without triggering failure*
    - get issue to trigger failure, especially in TeamCity
    - write  test to demonstrate the problem
    - fix the problem
    - [ ] DoxyDemo action should be 'doxygen', not 'install'
- [ ] integrate targets #96
- [ ] merge unmerged branches
- [ ] clear recent stashes

title: Doxygen docsets
body:
The code to produce a Doxygen docset has been broken for some time. The method executes it return zero prior to attempting to run the docset code.
For now, we can view our documentation from Safari. However, to link from our code to its documentation, we need a docset available for Dash.

- [x] for recursive copy, change `cp -r` to `cp -R`, now recommended for portability
- [x] change `/Users/$USER' to `${HOME}` for AppCode compatibility

After these changes, several problems with building the docset remain:
- The `tar` call in the generated makefile fails; editing the file to use `bsdtar` does make the script run without failures.
    - *This problem may have been caused by tampering with the `/usr/bin/tar` alias when we were working on setting up gnu-tar.*
- When we have gotten it to run, it appears to have produced either documentation files or a proper index, but not both, and sometimes generates many errors.
